docs.title: Background
docs.description: This project has evolved over the two years of the GSF's existence.

frontMatter.author: Asim Hussain (@jawache)
frontMatter.abstract: Discussion of the history and evolution of this project in the GSF.

docs.title: Boavizta
docs.description: Boavizta is an environmental impact calculator that exposes an API we use in IEF to retrieve energy and embodied carbon estimates.

docs.title: Cloud Carbon Footprint
docs.description: "Cloud Carbon Footprint is an open source tool that provides visibility and tooling to measure, monitor and reduce your cloud carbon emissions. We use best practice methodologies to convert cloud utilization into estimated energy usage and carbon emissions, producing metrics and carbon savings estimates that can be shared with employees, investors, and other stakeholders." - CCF

docs.title: Cloud Instance Metadata
docs.description: This plugin allows you to determine an instance's CPU based on its instance name.

docs.title: Model Documentation
docs.description: Here you can find documentation for individual model implementations. Each file contains an explanation of the model, its parameters and return values and examples of how to invoke the model in Typescript and from an impl.

docs.title: SCI (software carbon intensity)
docs.description: SCI is the final value the framework ultimately aims to return for some component or application. It represents the amount of carbon emitted per functional unit.

docs.title: SCI-E (total energy)
docs.description: sci-e is a model that simply sums up the contributions to a component's energy use. The model retunrs energy which is used as the input to the sci-o model that calculates operational emissions for the component.

docs.title: SCI-M: embodied carbon
docs.description: Software systems cause emissions through the hardware that they operate on, both through the energy that the physical hardware consumes and the emissions associated with manufacturing the hardware. Embodied carbon refers to the carbon emitted during the manufacture and eventual disposal of a component. It is added to the operational carbon (carbon emitted when a component is used) to give an overall SCI score.

docs.title: SCI-O (operational emissions)
docs.description: Operational emissions refer to the carbon generated by a component while it is in use. It is the product of the energy used by the component in kWh and the grid intensity in gCO2e/kWh. The operational emissions are added to the embodied emissions (calculated using sci-m) to provide an overall SCI score for the component.

docs.title: Shell-imp
docs.description: The shell-imp is a wrapper enabling models external to IEF to be executed as part of an IEF pipeline. For example, you might have a standalone model written in Python. shell-imp spawns a subprocess to execute that Python model in a dedicated shell and pipes the results back into IEF's Typescript process.

docs.title: Teads' AWS Estimation Model
docs.description: Teads Engineering Team built a model for estimating AWS Instances energy usage. This model creates a power curve on a correlation to SPEC Power database. This allows the model to generate a power curve for any AWS EC2 instance type based on publicly available AWS EC2 Instance CPU data.

docs.title: Teads' CPU Estimation Model
docs.description: Teads Engineering team has built a model that is capable of estimating CPU usages across varying type of CPUs using a curve commonly known as Teads Curve.

docs.title: WattTime Grid Emissions Model
docs.description: Introduction

docs.title: Overview
docs.description: Impact Framework (IF) aims to make software carbon measurements easy.

docs.title: Computation Pipeline
docs.description: Introduction

frontMatter.abstract: How to process the outputs of an impact graph calculation, enriching it with grid emissions data, factoring in the functional unit, and time slicing to return a time series of SCI values.

docs.title: Durations
docs.description: Terminology

frontMatter.author: Asim Hussain (@jawache)
frontMatter.abstract: A core component of impact graphing is the concept of time and specifically a duration of time. This document describes the core concept of duration as related to the calculation of an impact graph.

docs.title: Granularity
docs.description: An Impact Graph (graph) can be created that is very coarse-grained, a single top-level component, with a single input of long duration.

frontMatter.author: Asim Hussain (@jawache)
frontMatter.abstract: Why granularity is important to impact graphing and the two main types of granularity you can add.

docs.title: Impact
docs.description: Introduction

docs.title: Impact Engine Framework
docs.description: A Framework to Model, Measure, siMulate and Monitor the environmental impacts of software.

docs.title: Impact Graph
docs.description: Introduction

frontMatter.author: Asim Hussain (@jawache)
frontMatter.abstract: An impact graph is the core construct in an Impact Engine Framework through which all the other components interact.

docs.title: Impact Model Plugin
docs.description: Calculating Impact Metric 's (outputs) for every component in an Impact Graph (graph) requires the use of an Impact Model (model) called through an Impact Model Plugin (model plugin).

frontMatter.author: Asim Hussain (@jawache)
frontMatter.abstract: Standardising the interface to measurement models.

docs.title: Impl (Impact YAML)
docs.description: - Impact YAML (IMPL) is a file format based on yaml  to represent an Impact Graph.

frontMatter.author: Asim Hussain (@jawache)
frontMatter.abstract: Describes the structure and purpose of Impact YAML, a file format to represent an Impact Graph.

docs.title: Specification
docs.description: Here you will find the IF specification.

docs.title: Inputs
docs.description: inputs are a core component of an Impact Graph (graph), and they form the primary input into an Impact Model Plugin (model).

frontMatter.abstract: Describes an input in the context of an Impact Graph.

docs.description: There are several places in an Impl file where you can add configuration for a model.

docs.title: IMPL writing guide
docs.description: The Impact Framework receives all its configuration and input data in the form of a yaml file known as an impl (input-yaml).

docs.title: Tutorials
docs.description: Here you can find tutorials and walk through guides for how to achieve several fundamnetal Impact Framework tasks, such as creating an impl, choosing models and creating new plugins.

metadata.title: Welcome
metadata.description: Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.

blogPosts.content:
[Docusaurus blogging features](https://docusaurus.io/docs/blog) are powered by the [blog plugin](https://docusaurus.io/docs/api/plugins/@docusaurus/plugin-content-blog).

Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the `blog` directory.

Regular blog authors can be added to `authors.yml`.

The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as:

- `2019-05-30-welcome.md`
- `2019-05-30-welcome/index.md`

A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images:

![Docusaurus Plushie](./docusaurus-plushie-banner.jpeg)

The blog supports tags as well!

**And if you don't want a blog**: just delete this directory, and use `blog: false` in your Docusaurus config.

metadata.title: MDX Blog Post
metadata.description: Blog posts support Docusaurus Markdown features, such as MDX.

blogPosts.content:
Blog posts support [Docusaurus Markdown features](https://docusaurus.io/docs/markdown-features), such as [MDX](https://mdxjs.com/).

:::tip

Use the power of React to create interactive blog posts.

```js
<button onClick={() => alert('button clicked!')}>Click me!</button>
```

<button onClick={() => alert('button clicked!')}>Click me!</button>

:::

metadata.title: Long Blog Post
metadata.description: This is the summary of a very long blog post,

blogPosts.content:
This is the summary of a very long blog post,

Use a `<!--` `truncate` `-->` comment to limit blog post size in the list view.

<!--truncate-->
